Your nervous system is doing what it's wired to do when something this important feels uncertain. This isn't irrational panic; this is your brain trying to protect you from a real threat. The fact that you can't just "relax" on command makes complete sense given what's at stake.

**The spiraling:** Yeah, I know exactly what you mean. You can see the spiral happening, you know it's not productive, and yet there you are anyway, stuck watching your mind run the same disaster scenarios on repeat. That gap between knowing something intellectually and actually being able to stop it—that's one of the most frustrating parts of anxiety. It's like being a passenger in your own head sometimes.

When you're in one of those spirals—2am, worst-case scenarios playing—what does it look like? Are we talking full-body panic (heart racing, can't breathe), or more like your mind just won't turn off and let you sleep?

**Reaching out:** Glad you did. "Didn't know what to say" usually means there's a lot going on and it all feels too big to put into words. You managed to get it out now, which is something.

exchanges.assistant:
**The "selective layoffs" torture:** Oh, that's brutal. You're right—the slow-motion version might actually be worse. At least a clean cut gives you information to work with. This way, you're stuck in limbo: can't plan, can't relax, can't do anything but wait while your nervous system stays locked in high alert. It's like being told there's a threat but not knowing when or if it's coming for you. Your body doesn't know how to stand down from that.

**Four days without real sleep:** That's when things start to break down. Your body's running on fumes, which makes everything harder—managing emotions, thinking clearly, tolerating uncertainty. The wired feeling, the ceiling-staring—that's your system stuck in overdrive with nowhere to go. It can't fight or flee from "maybe layoffs," so it just... revs.

One thing that might help when you're lying there wired: your body's in fight-or-flight mode with no outlet. Sometimes giving it a physical release helps more than trying to calm your mind. Cold water on your face for 30 seconds, or even doing pushups until your arms burn—sounds counterintuitive, but it can signal to your nervous system that the "threat" has been dealt with and it's safe to power down. Worth trying tonight?

**The snapping at your partner:** You're running on no sleep, facing a major threat, and they said the one thing guaranteed not to help. Yeah, you snapped. Doesn't mean you're broken or a bad partner—it means you're human and maxed out. The fact that you recognized it wasn't fair and you're aware of the tension says you're still showing up, even when you're fried.

**The numbness shift:** This is important. What you're describing—panic becoming baseline, the "whatever, probably getting laid off anyway"—that's not coping, that's your system starting to shut down from overload. It's like when a circuit breaker flips to protect the system. The catastrophizing was exhausting, so now your brain's trying a different strategy: emotional flatlining. Neither extreme is sustainable, but the numbness especially is worth watching. When you notice it, does anything still break through? Like, is there anything this week that made you feel something other than numb or panicked?

**Your mom's anxiety on top of yours:** Yeah, that's a whole extra layer. You're already carrying your own fear, and now you're also managing hers, reassuring her, absorbing her worry. It's like trying to bail water out of your own sinking boat while someone hands you their bucket too. Do you usually end up in that role with her—taking care of her feelings when you tell her something hard?

**"Normal stress vs actually broken":** Here's the thing—what you're describing is a pretty normal response to a genuinely threatening situation *and* it's also a sign your system is getting overwhelmed. Both can be true. The four days of no sleep, the shutdown/numbness, the snapping at your partner—those are red flags that you're hitting your limits, not that you're fundamentally broken. Your nervous system is doing what it does under sustained threat: it's trying every strategy it has (panic, hypervigilance, numbing out) to deal with something that can't actually be resolved until you get information you don't have yet.

The question isn't "am I broken," it's "how do I get through the next few weeks without completely burning out while I wait for answers I can't control?"

exchanges.assistant:
**The weird letdown after "good news":** This is actually really common—you spent weeks bracing for disaster, your whole system mobilized around that threat, and then suddenly the threat evaporates. Your brain and body don't just flip a switch and go "great, we're fine now." They're still running the program they've been running for weeks. The flatness you're feeling isn't a sign something's wrong with you—it's what happens when your nervous system has been in overdrive for so long that it doesn't know how to come down. The relief was real, but it was brief, because your body is still stuck in the trauma of the *waiting*, even though the outcome was okay.

It makes complete sense that you can't just celebrate. You were prepared for loss, and instead you got a reprieve—but that reprieve came with survivor's guilt, which is its own kind of weight.

**The guilt about your teammates:** This is hitting you hard, and of course it is. You didn't just get neutral news—you got saved while watching two people you work with get cut, including a single dad who has more at stake. Your brain is doing the math: "Why him and not me? I don't deserve this more than he does." That's not irrational. That's your conscience recognizing the randomness and unfairness of who stays and who goes. Survivor's guilt is real, and it's especially sharp when you can see the human cost up close.

Here's the thing, though: your relief and his loss aren't connected in a way you can fix. You didn't take his job. The system made a decision, and you both got caught in it differently. Feeling guilty doesn't undo what happened to him, and it doesn't make your own relief illegitimate. Both can be true: you're glad you're staying, *and* you wish he was too. That tension doesn't resolve neatly, and trying to force it into "I should just be happy" isn't going to work.

What would it look like to acknowledge both—to let yourself feel the relief *and* the guilt, without trying to flatten either one?

**Your partner's frustration:** They've been watching you suffer for weeks, and now that the threat is over, they want you to feel better. That makes sense from their side—they're probably relieved too, and they want to share that with you. But you're not there yet, and you can't just perform happiness to make them feel better. The fact that you told them you needed space to process, and they got it even though they were frustrated—that's still good communication. You're both navigating this in real time.

**Sleep still rough, flatness instead of panic:** You said "at least when I was panicking I was *feeling* something," and that's the core of it, isn't it? The panic was terrible, but it was *activating*—it gave you something to do, even if that something was just white-knuckling through. Now the threat is gone, and what's left is this hollow, flat space where the panic used to be. Your body doesn't know what to do with that. It's like you've been running at full speed for weeks, and now someone said "stop," but the momentum is still there.

This flatness is temporary. Your system is recalibrating. It's been stuck in threat mode for so long that it needs time to learn it's safe again. That doesn't happen overnight, especially when there's guilt layered on top of it. Give it a few more days—the sleep will start to regulate, the flatness will start to lift. In the meantime, if the flatness feels unbearable, one thing you could try: do something small that used to feel good before all this started. Not to force happiness, but just to remind your body what "normal" feels like. What's one thing you used to do before the restructuring chaos that felt easy or enjoyable?
